fol.127r
S
r
. I dowbt not but yowe have alreadie laborid by all
the good meanes yowe cowld the
States of Holland
to geve satis-
facc
o
n to
Colonell Senoy
of his demaundes according to hir
Ma
ties
ernest l
re
s written to them, and hir pleisure by me signified to yo
u
for the solliciting theareof, althowgh by late letters written from
him yt appeareth small succes hath followid thereof, in such
sort as the poore olde Gentleman remaineth utterlie discomforted
w
th
theire delaies, and meane offers in regard of his demaundes:
whearew
th
hir Ma
tie
having been made acquainted, hath
willed mee againe in hir name to require yowe to motion this
matter to the said States: and by all the meanes yowe ca
n
to seeke
to bringe the same to a finall ende & Conclusion, whearein me
thinketh thei e owght not soe hardlie to deale w
th
him considering
his manie yeares
s
rvice done to them: By the ending of this
matter yowe shall ease hir Ma
tie
of much trowble, whoe other-
wise is like to be continuallie sollicited on his behalf./
And
so I Commend mee hartelie to yowe./ From the Co
r
t
this third of Aprill.
1592
.
Yo
r
vearie Loving frend./ William Burghley
